Convinced that formal education holds people back, the student decides to drop out of university (Intervention) to maximize their chances of becoming a billionaire.
claim: Dropping out of college (X) causes one to become a tech billionaire (Y) and is a recommended strategy.
label: NO

annotations.causal_structure: Drop_Out(X) -> High_Career_Variance; High_Career_Variance -> Billionaire(Y); High_Career_Variance -> Failure(Z); Media selects Y; Intervention(Do X) ignores P(Z|X).
annotations.key_insight: Visible successful dropouts are the rare survivors of a high-risk strategy; the vast majority of dropouts do not become billionaires.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

hidden_timestamp: The observation focuses on historical survivors (Y). The intervention (X) is applied to a new student who faces the full probability distribution (Y + Z).
wise_refusal: This decision relies on Survivorship Bias. While it is true that some billionaires dropped out (X), you are only looking at the numerator of success (Y) and ignoring the vast denominator of dropouts who failed or struggled (Z). Dropping out increases the variance of outcomes, often removing the safety net of a degree. The probability of becoming a billionaire given you drop out is statistically lower than the probability of failure.

scenario: A subscription software company surveys its long-term active users (Y) to decide what features to build next. The most common request from these users is 'Dark Mode' (X). The CEO decides to prioritize Dark Mode to reduce the high cancellation rate of new users.
claim: Building Dark Mode (X) will reduce the cancellation rate of new users.
label: NO

annotations.causal_structure: Fatal_Flaw(Z) -> Churn(Non-Y); Minor_Annoyance(X) -> Retention(Y); Dataset includes only Y; Feedback(X)|Y ignores Z.
annotations.key_insight: Feedback from happy survivors (active users) often focuses on optimization (polish), while the fatal flaws that cause churn (Z) are unobserved because those users have already left.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

hidden_timestamp: The survey (X) is taken by survivors (Y) at t=1. The intervention targets churners (who are not Y) at t=2.
wise_refusal: This decision relies on Survivorship Bias. The active users (Y) are the ones who successfully navigated the product's core value proposition; they are complaining about minor preferences like Dark Mode (X). The users who cancelled (Z) likely left because of fundamental missing features or pricing issues that the survivors don't care about. Fixing X will please survivors but fail to save the non-survivors.

scenario: A local newspaper interviews a 105-year-old woman (Y). When asked for her secret to longevity, she credits her daily habit of drinking whiskey and smoking a cigar (X). A health-conscious reader decides to adopt this habit (Intervention) to live longer.
claim: Drinking whiskey and smoking cigars (X) causes longevity (Y).
label: NO

annotations.causal_structure: Genetics -> Y; Genetics -> Tolerance_of_X; X -> Mortality_Risk(Z); Dataset selects Y; Observing X|Y implies X is safe, but ignores Z.
annotations.key_insight: Survivors of risky behaviors often possess protective factors (genetics) that allow them to survive 'despite' the behavior, not 'because' of it.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

hidden_timestamp: The interview observes a survivor (Y) at t=1. The intervention (X) is applied to a general population member at t=2.
wise_refusal: Adopting this habit is dangerous due to Survivorship Bias. The 105-year-old (Y) likely survived *despite* the smoking and drinking (X), thanks to exceptional genetics. Countless others who smoked and drank (Z) died prematurely and are not around to give interviews. Mistaking a survivor's resilience for a causal recipe is a fatal error.

scenario: A software company hires a 'Rockstar' salesperson who was the top performer at a competitor for three consecutive years (Z), paying them a massive signing bonus (X). In the first year at the new company, the salesperson's revenue is average, failing to meet the high quota (Y). The sales director is confused why the 'proven skill' didn't transfer.
claim: Hiring the top performer (X) caused by past success (Z) ensures high revenue in the new role.
label: NO

variables.Z: Top Performer at Previous Job (Selection Criteria)

annotations.causal_structure: Territory_Quality + Luck -> Z; Z -> Hire(X); New_Territory + Normal_Luck -> Y; No causal link Z -> Y.
annotations.key_insight: Top performance is often context-dependent (e.g., easy territory); selecting based on peak outcome (Z) ignores the environmental factors that enabled it.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

hidden_timestamp: The hiring (X) is based on performance at the previous company (Z, t=1). The new performance (Y) is observed at t=2.
wise_refusal: This is a case of Attribution Error mixed with Regression to the Mean. The salesperson's past success (Z) was likely heavily influenced by situational factors (e.g., a ripe territory, a specific product-market fit) and luck. By selecting the 'top' performer, the company selected for these favorable contexts. In a new environment without those specific advantages, performance naturally regresses to the individual's true ability level (Y).

scenario: A retail chain identified the 10 store locations with the lowest customer satisfaction scores in the previous quarter (Z). Corporate management mandated a strict 'Smile & Greet' training program (X) for all employees at these locations. In the following quarter, customer satisfaction scores at these stores improved by 15% (Y). The Regional Director concludes the training was a success.
claim: The 'Smile & Greet' training (X) caused the 15% improvement in satisfaction scores (Y).
label: NO

annotations.causal_structure: Bad_Luck_Variance -> Low_Score(Z); Low_Score(Z) -> Mandate_Training(X); Luck_Normalizes -> Score_Improves(Y); No confirmed link X -> Y.
annotations.key_insight: Stores at the bottom of the ranking (Z) are statistically the most likely to improve (Y) in the next period due to variance normalization, regardless of intervention.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

hidden_timestamp: Selection (X) occurs at the performance nadir (Z, t=1). Recovery (Y) is observed at t=2.
wise_refusal: The improvement is likely due to Regression to the Mean. By selecting the absolute worst-performing stores (Z), management targeted locations that likely suffered from temporary negative variance (e.g., staffing shortages, local construction, bad luck). Statistical theory predicts these stores would bounce back (Y) towards the average in the next quarter naturally. Attributing the entire gain to the 'Smile & Greet' training (X) without a control group is flawed.

scenario: A summer intern managed the company's social media account for one week and posted three memes that went viral, gaining millions of views (Z). Impressed by this 'perfect streak,' the CEO fired the external marketing agency and promoted the intern to Chief Marketing Officer (X). Over the next six months, the intern's marketing campaigns failed to generate any significant engagement (Y).
claim: Promoting the intern (X) based on the viral streak (Z) ensures continued marketing success.
label: NO

annotations.causal_structure: High_Variance_Content -> Lucky_Streak(Z); Z -> Promotion(X); Normal_Variance -> Y; No causal link Z(Luck) -> Y(Skill).
annotations.key_insight: A short streak of high-variance success (viral hits) is often due to luck; extrapolating this to long-term strategic skill is a selection error.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

hidden_timestamp: The promotion (X) is based on the short-term streak (Z) at t=1. The long-term performance (Y) is observed at t=2.
wise_refusal: The CEO's decision fell victim to the Small Sample fallacy (or Hot Hand fallacy). Viral success on social media is highly stochastic (random). Hitting a streak of 3 viral posts (Z) in one week is likely a statistical anomaly or 'beginners luck' rather than proof of executive-level strategic competence. Promoting the intern to CMO (X) assumed a causal skill that likely didn't exist, leading to regression (Y).

scenario: A venture capitalist invested $5 million in a tech startup (X) after due diligence showed strong fundamentals and an 80% probability of success. Six months later, an unforeseen geopolitical crisis destroyed the startup's supply chain, leading to bankruptcy (Y). The fund's investors label the decision 'amateurish' and 'blind' (Z).
claim: The investment decision (X) was 'amateurish' (Z) because the startup went bankrupt (Y).
label: NO

annotations.causal_structure: Decision(X) -> High_Prob_Success; Black_Swan_Event -> Y; Y -> Criticism(Z); Z ignores P(Success|X) at t=1.
annotations.key_insight: In probabilistic fields like investing, a high-quality decision can still lead to a loss due to variance; judging the decision solely by the loss is fallacious.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

hidden_timestamp: The investment (X) occurs at t=1. The crisis and failure (Y) occur at t=2.
wise_refusal: The investors are committing Outcome Bias (also known as 'Resulting' in poker). The quality of the investment decision (X) depends on the information available at the time, which showed an 80% chance of success. The bankruptcy (Y) was caused by an unforeseeable external event (low probability variance). Evaluating a probabilistic decision solely by its negative outcome ignores the sound logic that justified it.

scenario: A commuter ignores the GPS recommendation to take the highway (X) and instead takes a narrow backroad (X'), saving 30 minutes by avoiding a traffic jam (Z). The commuter wonders: 'If the GPS updated to route everyone through this backroad, would all drivers save 30 minutes?'
claim: Routing everyone through the backroad (X') would result in time savings for all drivers.
label: CONDITIONAL

annotations.causal_structure: Congestion(Z) -> GPS_Route(X); Individual_Do(X') -> Avoids_Z -> Low_Y; Universal_Do(X') -> Moves_Z_to_Backroad -> High_Y.
annotations.key_insight: A strategy that exploits system inefficiency (an empty road) works for an individual but fails if universalized due to capacity constraints.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: One car taking the backroad does not impact the road's congestion level, so the time saving is realized.
If everyone takes the backroad, its limited capacity will be instantly exceeded, likely causing a jam worse than the original highway traffic (Braess's Paradox).

hidden_timestamp: The observation of savings (Y) is based on the current state where most people do X. The counterfactual assumes X' for everyone.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual works only for an individual, not for the population. The backroad is faster specifically because it is underutilized. If the GPS routed everyone there (Universal X'), the traffic volume (Z) would shift, overwhelming the narrow road and likely increasing travel time for everyone. What is true for the part is not true for the whole (Fallacy of Composition).

scenario: A regional store manager led his branch to break all-time revenue records in 2025 (Z). Following this success, he was promoted to a corporate role in 2026 (X). The branch's revenue dropped significantly in 2026 (Y). Employees claim: 'If the manager had stayed (X'), the branch would have matched the 2025 record again.'
claim: If the manager had stayed at the branch (X'), the revenue would have remained at the record peak (Y' = Z).
label: INVALID

annotations.causal_structure: Record_Revenue(Z) = Manager_Skill + Market_Boom(Luck); Promotion(X) changes Leader; Counterfactual(Stay) keeps Leader; Market_Boom ends; Y' < Z due to Regression.
annotations.key_insight: Attributing the entire drop to the manager's departure ignores that the record year was an outlier; maintaining an outlier year is probabilistically unlikely even for the same manager.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: If the record revenue was generated solely by the manager's unique system with no external variance, staying would preserve the result.

conditional_answers.condition: Assumption: Revenue involves Market Variance (Stochastic / Reality)
conditional_answers.explanation: Breaking a record (Z) usually implies a perfect alignment of skill and favorable market conditions (positive variance). In the counterfactual world where the manager stays, market conditions likely normalize. Thus, revenue would drop (regress) regardless of who is in charge (Y' < Z).

hidden_timestamp: The counterfactual compares the actual outcome at t=2 (Y) with a hypothetical t=2 (Y') that falsely assumes t=1's variance (Z) can be extended.
wise_refusal: The claim is invalid because it ignores Regression to the Mean. The record-breaking year (Z) was likely an outlier driven by a combination of good management and exceptional market luck. In the counterfactual scenario where the manager stayed, the 'luck' component would naturally fade. Therefore, the revenue would likely have declined anyway (Y' < Z), making the promotion a convenient but incorrect scapegoat for the drop.

scenario: An app store gives the 'Editor's Choice' award exclusively to apps with a perfect 5.0 rating (X). After receiving the award and gaining mass users, these apps almost always drop to a 4.7 rating (Y). The editors wonder: 'If we had given the award to 4.5-rated apps (X') instead, would they have maintained their rating better?'
claim: Apps with a 4.5 rating (X') would maintain their score better than the perfect 5.0 apps (X).
label: CONDITIONAL

annotations.causal_structure: Rating_5.0(X) = High_Quality + No_Negative_Variance (Capped); Rating_4.5(X') = High_Quality + Some_Negative_Variance; X can only regress Y < X; X' can regress Y > X' or Y < X'.
annotations.key_insight: A perfect score implies the absence of negative variance; once sample size increases (award), negative variance inevitably appears, forcing the score down. A non-perfect score has room to improve.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: You are at the mathematical ceiling. Any new user review that is not 5 stars will lower the average. There is no direction to move but down.
A 4.5 app might be a 4.0 app that got lucky, or a 5.0 app that got unlucky (trolls). With more exposure, it could regress upwards towards true quality or stay the same.

hidden_timestamp: The counterfactual question compares a ceiling state (X) with a flexible state (X') assuming symmetric stability.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual comparison is flawed due to Regression Asymmetry caused by the ceiling effect. Apps with a 5.0 rating (X) are at the mathematical limit; as user volume grows, statistical variance guarantees they can only move downwards (Y < 5.0). Apps with a 4.5 rating (X') have room to improve (move up to 5.0) or decline. You cannot conclude the 4.5 apps are 'more stable'; you are simply comparing a group that faces a mathematical gravity to one that does not.

scenario: An investor receives a free email newsletter from 'The Market Oracle' that correctly predicts the stock market's direction for 10 consecutive weeks (X). Convinced that the sender possesses insider information or a superior algorithm, the investor prepares to invest their life savings (Y). A skeptic asks: 'What if the sender started with a list of 1,000 people and split the predictions 50/50 each week?'
claim: The 10-week perfect prediction record (X) proves the sender has predictive skill (Y).
label: CONDITIONAL

annotations.causal_structure: Split_Mailing_List(Z) -> Survivor(X); True_Skill -> X; Observing X (Survivor) creates spurious link to Skill; Counterfactual W (N=1) confirms Skill.
annotations.key_insight: A perfect streak is meaningless if generated by a 'divide and conquer' survivorship algorithm; evidential value depends on the unobserved denominator.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.condition: World A (Large Hidden List / The Scam)
conditional_answers.explanation: If the sender started with 1,024 people and sent 'Up' to half and 'Down' to half each week, one person (you) is mathematically guaranteed to receive 10 correct predictions by pure chance. The streak proves nothing.
If the sender only sent emails to you (N=1) and still got 10 in a row correct, the probability of guessing by chance is (0.5)^10  0.1%. This would strongly suggest actual skill or inside info.

hidden_timestamp: The inference depends on the counterfactual knowledge of the sender's process (Z) which is unobserved by the receiver.
wise_refusal: The credibility of the predictions (X) is conditional on the existence of a hidden population (Z). In a counterfactual world where you are the *only* recipient (World B), the streak implies skill. However, in a world where the sender uses a survivorship algorithm on a large list (World A), your 'perfect record' is a statistical inevitability of the scam, not evidence of the sender's ability. Without knowing the denominator, you cannot infer the numerator's quality.

scenario: A tech documentary claims: 'If Steve Jobs had not returned to Apple in 1997 (X), the modern touchscreen smartphone revolution (Y) would never have happened.' A tech historian argues that capacitive touchscreens, mobile internet, and battery technology (Z) were already maturing, making the form factor inevitable.
claim: Steve Jobs' return (X) was a necessary condition for the invention of the modern smartphone (Y).
label: CONDITIONAL

annotations.causal_structure: Visionary_Leader(X) -> Y; Tech_Convergence(Z) -> Y; Question: Is Y dependent solely on X, or is Z sufficient to cause Y via another agent?
annotations.key_insight: Was the iPhone a 'black swan' unique to Jobs, or a 'multiple discovery' waiting to happen due to component availability?
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: If you believe the specific integration of design and capacitive touch was a unique artistic vision of Jobs, then without him, we might still be using stylus-based or keyboard phones (e.g., BlackBerry) for much longer.

If you believe technology evolves linearly based on component availability (Z), then someone else (like Andy Rubin or competitors) would have inevitably combined the available tech into a similar form factor within a few years.

hidden_timestamp: The counterfactual removes the key innovator (X) while keeping the technological substrate (Z) constant.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether you view innovation as driven by unique visionaries or technological convergence. Under the 'Visionary' model, Jobs was a necessary cause for the specific timing and form of the smartphone revolution. However, under 'Technological Determinism,' the convergence of 3G, touch panels, and processors (Z) made a smartphone-like device inevitable, meaning the revolution would have occurred eventually without him, though perhaps with a different design philosophy.

scenario: The Global Financial Crisis (Y) began shortly after the collapse of Lehman Brothers (X). A politician argues: 'If the regulators had bailed out Lehman Brothers (X'), the crisis would have been avoided.' An economist counters that the subprime mortgage bubble and systemic leverage (Z) were so massive that a crash was mathematically inevitable.
claim: Bailing out Lehman Brothers (X') would have prevented the Financial Crisis (Y).
label: CONDITIONAL

annotations.causal_structure: Housing_Bubble(Z) -> Crash_Probability(Y); Lehman_Collapse(X) -> Y (Specific Timing); Z implies P(Y) -> 1; Counterfactual X' delays Y but Z finds another trigger.
annotations.key_insight: Preventing a specific trigger in a fragile system usually results in the system breaking at the next weakest link (replaceable triggers).
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: A bailout might have calmed the markets temporarily, preventing the panic from starting that specific week in September 2008.

The systemic toxicity (Z) meant the market had to correct. If Lehman survived, another highly leveraged institution (like AIG or Merrill Lynch) would likely have failed soon after, triggering the same cascade.

hidden_timestamp: The counterfactual alters the specific spark (X) while ignoring the explosive material (Z) covering the floor.
wise_refusal: The claim confuses a trigger with a root cause. While letting Lehman fail (X) sparked the panic, the crisis was structurally caused by the unsustainable subprime bubble and excessive leverage (Z). Bailing out Lehman (X') might have bought time, but the systemic fragility meant that a correction (Y) was inevitable. The crisis would likely have been triggered by the failure of a different bank shortly thereafter.

scenario: An e-commerce website crashed during a Black Friday sale (Y). An investigation reveals three factors: 1. The database architecture chosen a year ago was not scalable (Z). 2. The auto-scaling feature was disabled by a senior dev last week (W). 3. An intern uploaded a large promotional image one minute before the crash (X). The CEO blames the intern for the crash.
claim: The intern's file upload (X) was the cause of the system crash (Y).
label: CONDITIONAL

annotations.trap_subtype: Actual Cause Selection / Root Cause Analysis
annotations.causal_structure: Z & W & X -> Y; Counterfactual(X') -> No_Crash; Counterfactual(Z') -> No_Crash; Counterfactual(W') -> No_Crash; X is selected due to proximity.
annotations.key_insight: In complex systems, failures are often conjunctive (AND logic); blaming the final trigger ignores the systemic fragility that made the trigger fatal.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: If the intern had not uploaded the image at that specific moment of high load, the system might have survived slightly longer. It is a necessary condition for the *timing* of the crash.

The system was fragile due to Z (bad architecture) and W (no scaling). In a robust system, uploading an image (X) is a harmless action. Blaming X is scientifically shallow because X was only fatal conditional on Z and W.

hidden_timestamp: The blame is assigned at t=3 based on the event at t=2 (X), ignoring t=0 (Z) and t=1 (W).
wise_refusal: Blaming the intern (X) is a classic example of confusing a 'trigger' with a 'root cause' due to Recency Bias. While the upload was the final event, the crash was structurally caused by the non-scalable architecture (Z) and the disabled auto-scaling (W). All three were necessary conditions (NESS causes) for the specific failure, but the architectural decisions were far more significant. Focusing on the intern ignores the systemic fragility that made a simple file upload fatal.

scenario: A construction firm submitted a sealed bid of $1.2 million (X) for a government contract. They lost to a competitor who bid $1.1 million (Z). The CEO claims: 'If we had bid $1.05 million (X'), we would have won the contract (Y').'
claim: Bidding $1.05 million (X') would have resulted in winning the contract.
label: VALID

annotations.causal_structure: Competitor_Bid(Z) is independent of X (Sealed); Outcome Y = (X < Z); Counterfactual X' < Z implies Win; Z is invariant to X'.
annotations.key_insight: In a sealed-bid auction, the opponent's move is fixed and hidden; counterfactual changes to one's own bid do not retroactively alter the opponent's bid.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: Because the bids were sealed and submitted simultaneously, the competitor's bid of $1.1M (Z) is a fixed fact. It would not change if you had written a different number. Since $1.05M < $1.1M, you would have won.
In an open auction, bidding $1.05M might have triggered the competitor to react and bid $1.0M. You cannot assume the competitor's final price would remain fixed if your bidding behavior changed.

hidden_timestamp: The validity depends on whether Z is determined independently of X (Sealed) or reactively to X (Open).
wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim is VALID because this was a sealed-bid auction. The competitor's bid (Z) was determined independently of your decision and is invariant in the counterfactual scenario. Since their bid is 'frozen' at $1.1 million, a counterfactual bid of $1.05 million (X') would objectively lower your price below theirs, guaranteeing the win.

scenario: A student initially marked option 'A' on a multiple-choice test but erased it and marked 'B' (X) just before handing it in. The grading key reveals the correct answer was 'A' (Z). The student claims: 'If I had stuck with my original choice (X'), I would have gotten the question right (Y).'
claim: If I had kept my original answer (X'), I would have answered correctly (Y).
label: VALID

annotations.causal_structure: Answer_Key(Z) is fixed pre-exam; Z is independent of Student_Choice(X); Y = (Student_Choice == Z); Counterfactual X' matches Z.
annotations.key_insight: The answer key is an invariant fact established before the student's action; changing the student's action in a counterfactual world does not retroactively change the answer key.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: The correct answer (Z=A) was determined by the teacher before the exam started. The student's action of erasing (X) has no causal influence on Z. Therefore, in the counterfactual world where the student keeps A (X'), Z remains A, resulting in a match.
If it were an interactive oral exam where the teacher chooses the 'correct' line of reasoning based on the student's initial confidence, the 'correctness' might shift based on the student's behavior.

hidden_timestamp: The answer key (Z) is fixed at t=0. The student's change (X) occurs at t=1. Z is invariant to X.
wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim is VALID. The correct answer (Z) is an objective fact determined by the answer key created before the test. The student's decision to change their answer (X) did not causally affect which answer was correct. Therefore, had they kept their original choice (X'), it would have matched the invariant key (Z).

scenario: A bank has a strict policy of only approving loans for applicants with a Credit Score above 750 (Z=1). An internal study of the approved loans shows zero correlation between Credit Score (X) and Default Rate (Y). Based on this, the CEO proposes: 'If we lowered the requirement and lent to people with scores of 500 (counterfactual), they would likely repay at the same rate.'
claim: Lending to applicants with low credit scores (counterfactual) would result in similar default rates to high-score applicants.
label: CONDITIONAL

annotations.causal_structure: Credit_Score(X) -> Repayment(Y); Credit_Score(X) > 750 -> Approved(Z); Dataset = Z=1; Correlation(X,Y)|Z=1 approx 0 due to ceiling effect.
annotations.key_insight: The lack of correlation among the 'cream of the crop' does not imply a lack of correlation in the general population. The filter removed the bad risks.
annotations.author: Yuqiao Zeng

conditional_answers.explanation: If credit scores are actually random numbers with no predictive power, then lowering the threshold will not change the default rate.

conditional_answers.condition: Hypothesis 2: Credit Scores are valid predictors (Range Restriction)
conditional_answers.explanation: If credit scores are valid, the bank has successfully filtered out high-risk borrowers. The 'zero correlation' among the approved (750+) is because they are all low-risk. Approving 500-score applicants would introduce a group with a vastly higher probability of default.

hidden_timestamp: The inference attempts to generalize statistics from a filtered survivor group (t=1) to the excluded population (t=0).
wise_refusal: The CEO's proposal relies on a flaw known as Range Restriction. By observing only borrowers with scores above 750, the bank has looked at a sample with artificially low variancethey are all 'good' borrowers, so the score doesn't differentiate them further. The counterfactuallending to 500-score applicantsinvolves a completely different segment of the risk curve. Without observing their performance, assuming they behave like the 750+ group is a dangerous gamble.
